title: Bedil tombak
text:
Bedil tombak or bedil tumbak is a type of early firearm from the <a href="Malay%20Archipelago">Malay</a> archipelago. The weapon consist of a gun or small cannon mounted on a wooden pole, forming a type of weapon known as "pole gun" ("stangenbüchse" in <a href="German%20language">German</a>).
Etymology.
The word "bedil" a term in <a href="Malay%20language">Malay language</a> meaning gun (any type of gun, from small pistol to large siege gun). The word "tombak" or "tumbak" means spear, pike, or lance.
History.
The introduction of gunpowder-based weapon in Nusantara archipelago can be traced back from <a href="Mongol%20invasion%20of%20Java">Mongol invasion of Java</a> (1293), where the Chinese-Mongol troops used cannon ("<a href="Hu%20dun%20pao">pao</a>") against the forces of <a href="Kediri%20Kingdom">Kediri</a> in Daha. Between 14th-15th century, numerous local sources mentioned about bedil (gun or gunpowder-based weapon), but since this is a broad term it is difficult to discern what type of weapon used in a passage. A small hand-gun dated from the year 1340 thought to be Chinese was found in Java, but the dating may have been wrong.
<a href="Ma%20Huan">Ma Huan</a> (<a href="Zheng%20He">Zheng He</a>'s translator) visited Java in 1413 and took notes about the local customs. His book, <a href="Yingya%20Shenglan">Yingya Shenlan</a>, explained about Javanese marriage ceremony: when the husband was escorting his new wife to the marital home, various instruments were sounded, including gongs, drums, and "<a href="huochong">huochong</a>" (fire-tube or <a href="hand%20cannon">hand cannon</a>). It is probable that Javanese hand cannon is modelled after Chinese ones. A Chinese pole cannon from 1421 A.D. has been found in the island of Java bearing the name of <a href="Emperor%20Yongle">Emperor Yongle</a> (1403-1425). The gun's ignition hole is protected from the rain by a cover connected with hinge.
<a href="Duarte%20Barbosa">Duarte Barbosa</a> recorded abundance of gunpowder-based weapons in <a href="Java">Java</a> ca. 1514. The Javanese were deemed as expert gun caster and good artillerymen. The weapon made there including one-pounder cannons, long muskets, "spingarde" (arquebus), "schioppi" (hand cannon), <a href="Greek%20fire">Greek fire</a>, guns (cannons), and other fire-works. In <a href="Capture%20of%20Malacca%20%281511%29">1511 siege of Malacca</a>, the Malays were using cannons, matchlock guns, and "firing tubes".
Local "babad" (historical text) of post-17th century occasionally mention bedil tombak, but they are hard to date because the "babad"s were in the form of "pupuh" (poem). In <a href="Lombok">Lombok</a> example of such "babad"s were babad Lombok, babad Mengui, and babad Sakra. They are also mentioned in Sundanese and Balinese texts. During the Bali-Lombok war (ca. early 19th century-end of 19th century), a part of Karangasem troops were armed with bedil tombak.
